news.article_text:
What Happened?

Shares of tobacco company Altria (NYSE:MO) fell 7.3% in the morning session after the company reported third-quarter results where revenues missed expectations, overshadowing an in-line result for earnings per share. news.headline: Trump administration moves to overrule state laws protecting credit reports from medical debt
news.summary: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has drafted what’s known as an interpretative rule. It says the FCRA should preempt any state laws or regulations when it comes to how debt should be reported. More than a dozen states like New York and Delaware prohibit the reporting of medical debt.
news.article_text:
NEW YORK (AP) — The Trump administration is moving to overrule any state laws that may protect consumers’ credit reports from medical debt and other debt issues.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has drafted what’s known as an interpretative rule related to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, interpreting the law in a way that says the FCRA should preempt any state laws or regulations when it comes to how debt should be reported to the credit bureaus like Experian, Equifax and Trans Union.

news.article_text:
Dive Brief:

Skippy peanut butter and SPAM maker Hormel Foods finance chief Jacinth Smiley has stepped down from her position to pursue other opportunities, the company said in a Wednesday press release and securities filing.

Hormel tapped Paul Kuehneman, its vice president and controller, to serve as interim CFO in a move that was effective Oct. 27, according to the release.

news.headline: Trump administration moves to overrule state laws protecting credit reports from medical debt
news.summary: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has drafted what’s known as an interpretative rule. It says the FCRA should preempt any state laws or regulations when it comes to how debt should be reported. More than a dozen states like New York and Delaware prohibit the reporting of medical debt.
news.article_text:
NEW YORK (AP) — The Trump administration is moving to overrule any state laws that may protect consumers’ credit reports from medical debt and other debt issues.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has drafted what’s known as an interpretative rule related to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, interpreting the law in a way that says the FCRA should preempt any state laws or regulations when it comes to how debt should be reported to the credit bureaus like Experian, Equifax and Trans Union.

Waste management services provider Waste Management (NYSE:WM) missed Wall Street’s revenue expectations in Q3 CY2025, but sales rose 14.9% year on year to $6.44 billion. Its non-GAAP profit of $1.98 per share was 1.6% below analysts’ consensus estimates.

Is now the time to buy WM? Find out in our full research report (it’s free for active Edge members).

Waste Management (WM) Q3 CY2025 Highlights:

Revenue: $6.44 billion vs analyst estimates of $6.51 billion (14.9% year-on-year growth, 1% miss)

news.headline: Waste Management (WM) Margin Decline Challenges Reliable Income Narrative Ahead of Slower Growth Forecasts
news.summary: Waste Management posted a 12% average annual increase in earnings over the last five years, but this year, earnings slipped. Revenue is expected to grow by 5.7% annually and earnings by 13.6% per year, both trailing the broader US market. Still, the company
news.article_text: Waste Management (WM) posted a 12% average annual increase in earnings over the last five years, but this year, earnings slipped, with net profit margins narrowing to 10.3% from 12.3% a year ago. Looking ahead, revenue is expected to grow by 5.7% annually and earnings by 13.6% per year, both trailing the broader US market. news.summary: The company is experiencing pricing pressure in the insurance market, particularly in property and large complex segments. Despite this, they still expect mid- to high single-digit organic revenue growth in Risk & Broking for the year.
news.article_text: Q : How much of the Risk & Broking organic revenue results in the third quarter were due to unusual wins that might not recur? A : Carl Hess, President and CEO, explained that the 6% growth in Risk & Broking was driven by their specialization strategy and investments in talent, data, and technology. news.article_text: Health, Wealth & Career : Total revenues of $1.2 billion decreased 5% year over year (6% increase on a constant currency and 4% increase on an organic basis). news.article_text:
Willis Towers Watson (WTW) reported $2.29 billion in revenue for the quarter ended September 2025, representing no change year over year. EPS of $3.07 for the same period compares to $2.93 a year ago.

The reported revenue represents a surprise of +0.53% over the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $2.28 billion. With the consensus EPS estimate being $3.00, the EPS surprise was +2.33%.
